I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  (i)  a proposed

I. 

THE PROPOSAL

II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
During the 1970s and 1980s, economic growth in Indonesia was led by the oil and mineral
industry  sectors  that  thrived  in  the  inward-oriented  and  import  substitution  policy  regime.  Oil
revenues helped speed up industrialization through extensive public investment in upstream and
capital  intensive  industries.  Following  the  collapse  of  oil  prices  in  the  world  market,  Indonesia
faced  balance  of  payment  difficulties  that  underscored  the  urgency  to  reorient  its  industrial
strategy  to  achieve  greater  diversification  toward  the  non-oil  sector.  Starting  in  the  mid-1980s,
Indonesia repositioned itself to adopt an export-oriented industrial strategy with emphasis on non-
oil industries and private sector participation. The main elements of the industrial reform packages
adopted  from  the  mid-1980s  to  1993  were  a  greater  openness  to  private  sector  and  foreign
investment  (although  entry  prohibitions  remained  in  selective  areas),  and  across-the-board
reductions  in  nominal  tariffs.  These  reforms  were  complemented  by  a  limited  reorganization  of
customs, ports, and shipping operations. These liberalization efforts spurred more than a decade
of rapid economic growth based on high rates of industrial growth, much of it in export-oriented
industries.  Economic  growth  contributed  to  a  significant  decline  in  poverty  between  1976  and
1996.

3.
Despite  considerable  structural  transformation,  significant  industrial  policy  distortions
remained or emerged. These included (i)  wide prevalence of government-sanctioned monopolies
(such  as  Agency  for  National  Logistics  [BULOG])  and  cartel  arrangements,  entry  restrictions  on
“sensitive”  or  “strategic”  subsectors  (plywood,  cement,  fertilizer,  sugar  processing,  aircraft
manufacturing, steel); (ii) protection, on an ad hoc basis, for selected sectors and products; and
(iii) distribution controls.

These  distortions  diverted  significant  resources  to  industries  that  were  not  competitive;
4.
encouraged  rent  seeking;  promoted  concentration  in  industrial  structure;  and  raised  business
costs, official and unofficial, associated with the complex regulations, approvals, and licenses still

slower  growth  rates  by  the  mid-1990s,  and  reduced  competitiveness  relative  to  other  high-
performing  economies  in  Asia.  These  developments  took  place  when  Indonesia  was  becoming
more  integrated  into  the  international  economy  and  facing  increased  competition;  together  they
contributed to increasing the country’s vulnerability to external shocks.

through  the  unprecedented  contraction  in  manufacturing,  which  had  been  the  engine  of  growth.

Indonesia  responded  to  the  economic  crisis  by  adopting  a  macroeconomic  stabilization
6.

World  Bank,  and  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  A  major  component  of  the  reforms  is  bank

formulated  a  comprehensive  industrial  deregulation  and  liberalization  program  to  dismantle
remaining distortionary policies.

ADB  provided  TA  for  the  formulation  of  a  consistent  industry  and  trade  sector  strategy.2
7.
The  TA  examined,  in  depth,  the  industrial  structure,  policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  issues.
Within  this  context,  a  review  was  conducted  of  the  commercial  legal  environment,  tariffs  and
nontariff  barriers,  domestic  trade  and  distribution  constraints,  investment  laws  and  regulations,
customs  administration  and  trade  facilitation,  and  export  incentives  and  promotion.  The  TA  also
analyzed distortions and constraints to private enterprises including small and medium enterprises
(SMEs). Based on this economic and sector work, since 1997 ADB has pursued an active policy
dialogue with the Government and other funding agencies to promote a competitive, transparent
and predictable policy environment that provides a level playing field for all enterprises.

8.
In  1998  ADB  fielded  reconnaissance  missions  in  April  and  July,  and  the  Fact-Finding
Mission in September to reach an understanding with the Government on the objectives, scope,
and  pace  of  the  industrial  and  trade  policy  reforms  under  the  Program.  The  Appraisal  Mission3

in  the  Development  Policy  Letter  and  attached  Policy  Matrix  (Appendix  1).  It  was  followed  by

fielded in November and December 1999 to reach final understandings. The program framework
and its monitoring arrangements are given in Appendix 2.

III.

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT

A. 

Government Strategy and Policies

9.
The  democratic  political  transition  in  Indonesia  has  given  it  a  historic  opportunity  to
reinforce  and  consolidate  its  reform  efforts,  accelerate  economic  recovery  and  improve  the  well
being of its people. While focusing on economic recovery and job creation as key tasks, the new
government  has  reconfirmed  its  commitment  against  corruption,  collusion  and  nepotism.  These
objectives will need to be achieved under tighter budgetary constraints due to the ongoing cost of
the financial crisis. Driven by political and economic imperatives, there is thus a need for a policy
agenda that is cost efficient and effective.

10.
The tremendous political changes in Indonesia have been caused by, and have increased,
the  growing  power  of  civil  society.  This  has  manifested  itself  in  the  form  of  newly  empowered
lobby  groups  and  organizations,  and  generally  greater  freedom  of  expression.  The  immediate

Responding to these demands, Indonesia’s democratically elected Parliament has adopted State
Policy Guidelines that define an agenda for reviving the economy and laying the foundation for a

11.
The  Government’s  economic  stabilization  program  is  complemented  by  wide-ranging
structural reforms to (i) adopt an expansionary fiscal policy, (ii) improve monetary management to
be steered by an independent Bank Indonesia (BI), (iii) increase the efficiency and transparency
of  public  sector  activities,  (iv) restructure  banks  and  corporates,  (v) preserve  productive  assets
and ease pressure on the exchange rate, (vi) improve governance at public sector and corporate
levels, and (vii) strengthen social protection and shield the poor and other vulnerable groups.

12.
Key emphasis has been placed on implementing banking reforms. At the same time, debt
restructuring  of  large  firms  is  underway  to  support  bank  restructuring.  The  Indonesia  Bank
Restructuring  Agency  (IBRA)  was  set  up  and  entrusted  with  legal  powers  to  deal  with  the  debt
resolution. The portfolio of nonperforming banks was transferred to IBRA, which closed a number
of  banks. Of the 160  private banks in 1997, 66 were closed, 12 taken over by the Government,
and  8  jointly  recapitalized  with  their  owners.  The  Government  has  issued  bonds  to  recapitalize
banks  that  have  potential  to  survive.  The  total  cost  of  recapitalization  is  expected  to  be  about
$89 billion, or 60 percent of GDP. Of the state banks, four were merged into an entity called Bank
Mandiri, which is undergoing restructuring. Robust measures were taken following the discovery
of  the  Bank  Bali  scandal.  To  restore  market  confidence  the  Bank  Bali  investigation  is  being
advanced,  and  systems  and  procedures  to  prevent  recurrence  are  being  strengthened;  the

B.

Recent Performance and Prospects

16.
As  a  result  of  the  Government’s  considerable  flexibility  and  prudence  in  economic
management,  Indonesia  is  emerging  from  the  worst  of  what  has  been  an  unprecedented
economic crisis. This is reflected in an across-the-board recovery which according to preliminary
estimates has resulted in a growth rate of gross domestic product (GDP) of about 0.3 percent in
1999.  This  contrasts  with  the  contraction  of  real  GDP  of  13.2  percent  in  1998.6  Prudent
macroeconomic  management,  tight  domestic  liquidity  conditions,  and  gradual  restoration  of
confidence in the rupiah has stabilized the exchange rate, which is presently at about Rp7,500 to
the  dollar.    A  major  accomplishment  was  the  reining  in  of  inflation,  with  the  annual  rate  in  1999
projected at 2 percent. This is much lower than the forecast 25 percent earlier in the year. This
deceleration is significant, as inflation peaked at around 78 percent in June 1998. Tight monetary
policy  and  the  agriculture  sector’s  recovery  following  the  El  Niño  episode  of  1997-1998,  helped
reduce inflation. As inflationary expectations subsided, the benchmark interest rate on one-month
Treasury bills has steadily declined, from a peak of 70 percent in August 1998 to about 13 percent
at present. A commensurate decline in bank deposit rates (with virtually unchanged lending rates)
has eliminated negative intermediation spreads for most banks.

17. While  rising  oil  prices  boosted  non-oil  export  revenues,  overall  export  revenues  declined
by about 7 percent in 1999. However, the weak overall export revenue performance masks more
robust export volume growth but this was mitigated by lower international prices for both natural
resource and manufactured exports. Manufactured exports are constrained by lack of access to
bank  finance  which  will  require  speedier  bank  restructuring.  Import  compression  declined  with
imports falling about 11 percent in 1999, in contrast to a fall of 30 percent in 1998. Capital goods
imports lagged in 1999, reflecting the fall in investment demand. However, intermediate imports,
crucial for sustaining recovery of exports and growth, stabilized in mid-year and grew by 5 percent
in  1999.  To  strengthen  export  performance,  the  Government  is  pursuing  trade  liberalization  and
has set up the Bank Export Indonesia as a one-stop shop to handle trade financing.

18.
Investment  activity  continues  to  be  depressed.  As  output  and  incomes  remain  low,  to
offset the low level of private investment and stimulate aggregate demand, the Government has
pursued an expansionary fiscal policy. The budget deficit for FY 1999/2000 is projected to rise to
4.3 percent  of  GDP  to  support  an  expansion  in  public  expenditures.  The  growing  costs  of

IV.

THE SECTOR

A. 

Background and Recent Performance

1.

Industrial Growth and Structural Transformation

21.
Indonesia’s  industrial  strategy  has  undergone  significant  changes  over  the  years.
Emphasis on import substitution up to 1983 and large-scale public sector involvement in industry
led  to  the  development  of  costly  capital-intensive  industries.  Between  1976  and  1983,
manufacturing value added grew at an average of 10 percent per annum, largely because of high
capital intensity rather than efficiency in its use.7

22.   Subsequently,  the  export-oriented  industrial  strategy  pursued  from  the  mid-1980s  to  the
mid-1990s focused on significant reductions in international trade barriers, and encouraged more
friendly  policies  toward  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI).  Fostering  greater  efficiency  in  markets,
these  policies  led  to  growth  of  export-oriented  industries  (including  garments,  textiles,  and
footwear), food processing, and construction. Following the shift in industrial strategy from import
substitution  to  export  orientation,  manufacturing  value  added  growth  rose  to  16  percent  per
annum  between  1984  and  1993.  The  total  factor  productivity  contribution  to  growth  rose  to
33 percent,  with  the  rest  of  the  growth  attributable  to  increments  in  capital  and  labor.  Despite
these  improvements,  the  level  of  productivity  and  efficiency  of  Indonesian  industry  compares
unfavorably with other high-performance Asian economies where total factor productivity growth
accounts  for  about  50  percent  of  increases  in  manufacturing  productivity.  Given  resource
constraints,  large  increments  in  labor  and  capital  inputs  are  no  longer  sustainable.  Productivity

2.

Size distribution of firms9 and Interfirm Linkages

25.
Indonesia’s corporate sector is characterized by a small number of relatively large export-
oriented  firms  and  large  domestic-oriented  firms.  In  1996,  the  formal  industry  sector  included
about 7,000 large firms, 6,000 medium firms, and 229,000 small firms. The large firms contributed
85 percent of manufacturing value added, and small, medium and cottage enterprises–5 percent
each. Relative to regional economies, Indonesia has not as yet fully exploited the potential of the
SME  sector,  although  small  enterprises  have  performed  relatively  well  in  terms  of  creating
employment. The contribution to value added of medium enterprises, however, declined to a low
of 5 percent in 1996 from a high of 14 percent in 1975.

26.
Between 1975 and 1996 the share of large firms in manufacturing employment increased
from  13  percent  to  35  percent;  the  share  of  small  enterprises  increased  from  7  percent  to
19 percent; and the share of cottage enterprises declined from 75 percent to 40 percent. What is
unusual by international experience is the initial increase of the share of medium enterprises from
5 percent in 1975 to 9 percent in 1986, followed by a decline to 6 percent in 1996.

28.

transformation of the industry sector.

29.
Relative  to  international  experience,  SMEs  in  Indonesia  are  underrepresented  as
subcontractors in the manufacture, service, and subassembly of components because the policy
environment  tended  to  encourage  large-scale  vertically  integrated  operations.  These  policy

greater SME participation. By developing interfirm linkages SMEs can provide assured and cost
effective  supply  of  manufactured  components  and  other  inputs  to  the  industrial  sector.  Such
subcontracting is flourishing in textiles and garments. Besides these vertical linkages, horizontal
interfirm  linkages  are  emerging  as  SMEs  are  finding  it  advantageous  to  locate  in  geographic
clusters.  These  clusters  are  largely  made  up  of  small  SMEs.  While  they  make  a  substantial
contribution  to  employment,  their  contribution  to  value  added  is  significantly  smaller.  Dynamic
SME clusters are usually based on linkups with larger firms that provide access to markets and
technologies that contribute to upgrading SME capability.

3.

Labor Standards

30.
Historically,  Indonesia’s  labor  standards  have  been  supported  by  a  legal  framework
advocating a centralized enforcement system for mandatory standards, rather than allowing labor
representatives  to  self-regulate.  Prospects  for  collective  action  were  limited  because  of  the
absence of independent trade unions to provide the institutional support and information base for
adequate labor representation and advocacy in disputes concerning labor standards. Without this
right,  workers  were  prevented  from  effectively  participating  in  activities  to  monitor  and  regulate
their  working  conditions.  Until  shortly  prior  to  the  crisis,  there  was  only  one  legally  recognized
union in the private sector, i.e., the Indonesia Workers Union.

31.
Greater  public  awareness  of  and  desire  to  seek  redress  for  work-related  grievances  has
increased  labor  actions  in  recent  years.  To  respond  to  this,  the  Ministry  of  Manpower  has
attempted  to  play  a  more  active  role  in  enforcing  mandated  labor  standards.  Unlike  in  the  past
when  labor  unrest  was  prompted  by  dismissals,  in  the  1990s,  labor  action  has  been  instigated
mainly  by  deteriorating  wages  and  working  conditions.  Principal  issues  were  the  lack  of
confidence in the officially sanctioned union to negotiate better working conditions and wages, the
weakness of dispute resolution mechanisms, and the limited independence of the bodies involved
in the mediation process.

32.
Poor working conditions affect worker morale and increase costs. Recognizing that the key
to ensuring humane and efficient working conditions and standards lies in allowing free collective
bargaining, the Government has embarked on mandating improved standards and providing the

 8

legal  basis  for  a  greater  role  to  be  played  by  independent  unions.  In  1998,  Indonesia  signed  a
letter of intent with the International Labor Organization (ILO) for the ratification of the seven core
ILO  conventions  covering  the  four  central  issues  of  (i) freedom  of  association,  (ii) forced  labor,
(iii) nondiscrimination, and (iv) child labor.10 As of June 1999, Indonesia is the only country in Asia
to  have  ratified  all  seven  core  conventions.  The Tripartite  Task  Force  consisting  of  unions,
Government,  and  employers  was  established  and  is  working  with  ILO  to  implement  the  core
standards.  With  ILO’s  assistance,  Indonesia  is  strengthening  labor  legislation  by  reviewing  the
Manpower  Act  and  preparing  laws  on  trade  unions  and  trade  union  disputes  settlement.  These
will aim to strike a balance between union monopoly and multiple unions and to include provision
for  promoting  the  principle  of  “most  representative  organization”  under  which  a  union  with  a
majority  will  have  exclusive  rights  for  collective  bargaining.  As  a  result  of  these  efforts,  trade
unions  now  number  18.  The  legal  and  regulatory  environment  as  well  as  actual  implementation
now compares favorably with other economies in the region. In June 1999, Indonesia was cited by
ILO in recognition of labor standards improvements.

B. 

Constraints and Issues

1.

Inadequate Commercial Law and Competition Framework

33.
The efficiency of the corporate restructuring process and ensuing economic recovery are
constrained by weaknesses in the legal system. Chief among these are an inadequate bankruptcy
law,  the  absence  of  a  law  on  acquisitions  and  mergers,  legal  uncertainty  over  land  titles  and
movable securities, and a deficient contract law. Problems of transparency and corruption in the
legal  system  are  other  key  impediments  to  the  growth  and  development  of  efficient  enterprises.
The  increased  sophistication  of  the  Indonesian  economy  and  the  closer  integration  with  world
markets in the last decade have increased the urgency for implementing an effective commercial
legal system.

Industrial performance and restructuring has been further affected by inadequacies of the
34.
legal and institutional framework to sustain and promote a truly competitive economy. Therefore,
the  enactment  of  a  competition  law  is  a  cornerstone  of  industrial  policy.  Experience  in  other
countries shows that it is essential to focus such a law on market conduct rather than on a firm’s
market  share.  This  implies  preventing  such  anticompetitive  practices  as  collusive  (or  horizontal)
agreements  to  fix  prices  and  market  shares.  Such  practices  should  be  per  se  illegal.  It  is  also
prudent to avoid legislating against certain non competitive practices that may increase consumer
welfare, such as joint ventures and various types of vertical restraints. These practices are better
addressed  by  weighing  their  costs  and  benefits.  Provisions  related  to  this  category  of  conduct
need to be grounded in economic analysis to ensure that rigid prohibitions are not automatically
imposed.  International  best  practice  suggests  that  exemptions  to  the  law  need  to  be  minimized
and the law’s coverage extended to State-owned-enterprises and other monopolies to ensure that
liberalization measures are not impaired by their conduct. A dedicated enforcement agency in the
form of a commission that is independent and has powers of investigation and legal sanction is
required to effectively implement competition law.

2.

between firms of different sizes, public ownership of specific industries, informal levies, marketing
restrictions,  price  controls,  and  special  assistance  (subsidies  and  tax  holidays)  to  specific  firms

A typical example is the cement industry, in which regulatory arrangements were based on

of subsidized fertilizers to farmers. All five urea fertilizer producers in Indonesia are State owned.

These pricing and marketing arrangements resulted in inefficient supply and consumption of urea

37.
Similarly, the importation and distribution of several oil products is controlled by the State-
owned oil and gas company (Pertamina) and two closely affiliated companies. Their monopolies
include solid and liquid lubricants, crude lubricant oil, ethylene, and propylene. Pertamina assigns
domestic distributors for these products. Industrial companies are allowed to import some of these
products for their own use (i.e., under importer-producer licenses). These import and distribution
restrictions increase the cost of basic industrial raw materials used by producers in downstream
industries like plastics, textiles, and footwear. Pertamina also has a retail monopoly for gasoline.
International experience indicates that a monopolistic market structure reduces the incentives for
efficiency  improvements  in  the  retail  sector.  Opening  up  the  distribution  and  retail  gasoline
subsector  to  competition  will  improve  efficiency  and  ensure  competitive  distribution  margins.  A
draft  law  is  to  be  submitted  to  Parliament  eliminating  Pertamina’s  monopoly  for  transportation,
storage,  transmission,  and  marketing.  On  enactment  of  the  law,  private  companies  may
participate  in  these  activities  after  obtaining  a  business  license.  Exploration  and  exploitation  will
be retained in the public sector, with private sector operations defined on the basis of contracts
with the Government.

38.
Restraints to competition in Indonesia have imposed costs through higher prices for basic
raw materials as well as for final goods; reduced consumer and business choice; increased cross-
subsidies, which benefit inefficient firms at the cost of efficient firms; and reduced incentives for
innovation  and  efficiency.  While  under  some  circumstances  unrestricted  markets  may  fail,  thus
justifying policy interventions in the public interest, the onus of proof that competition is causing
more  harm  than  good  should  be  on  the  proponents  of  restrictions.  In  this  context,  the  guiding
principle  for  deregulation  should  be  that  legislation  should  not  restrict  competition.  Temporary
restrictions  are  justifiable  if  their  public  benefits  outweigh  the  costs.  To  strengthen  competition,
existing  laws  and  regulations  must  be  reviewed,  and  institutional  mechanisms  developed  to
evaluate public or net benefit and review legislation that impedes competition.

3.

International Trade Protection

39.

a.

Investment Laws and Processes

47.
The  collapse  of  investment  during  the  crisis  underscores  the  need  for  a  policy  response
that  provides  a  stable  and  predictable  policy  regime  that  reduces  uncertainty  and  promotes
investor  confidence.  The  restrictive  legal  and  regulatory  regime,  entry  barriers  defined  by  the
negative  list  of  industries  and  the  lack  of  a  level  playing  field  and  transparency  in  investment
policy framework are major impediments to reviving investment growth. In 1998, the Government
revised  the  negative  investment  list  by  publishing  two  lists  (instead  of  one).  Presidential  Decree

new FDI, while Presidential Decree No. 99/1998 (i)  reserves 33 product groups for small firms,
and  (ii)  opens  26 product  groups  to  medium-  and  large-scale  investors,  but  only  in  partnership
with small firms/cooperatives.

48.
Besides the need to remove investment restrictions, the legal framework needs to ensure
consistency with competitive trends and liberalization in other aspects of the Indonesian economy.
In particular, the discrepancy between the relatively restrictive basic laws and subsequent reform
initiatives  has  resulted  in  unnecessary  confusion  and  lack  of  transparency  regarding  the  policy
framework  for  investment.13  The  existing  Foreign  Capital  Investment  Law  of  1967  and  the
Domestic Capital Investment Law of 1968 need to be repealed and replaced with an investment
law  that  establishes  a  transparent  framework  for  both  foreign  and  domestic  investors.  In
accordance with best practice, the law should provide for more simplified and uniform treatment of
investment  approvals,  whether  domestic  or  foreign;  improve  transparency;  and  reduce  the
opportunities for corruption, collusion, and nepotism by reducing and rationalizing the provision of
ad hoc fiscal and other special incentives to investment. Effective implementation of the new legal
and  regulatory  framework  will  require  a significant  reorientation  of  the  Investment  Board14  as  its
mandate  shifts  from  regulating  and  controlling  FDI  to  promoting  and  facilitating  both  FDI  and
domestic  investment  under  the  new  framework.  In  addition,  the  Government  will  need  to
streamline departments that traditionally regulated investment and maintain various types of price,
import, and distribution controls.

A.

Rationale

V.

THE PROGRAM

75.
The main challenge now facing policymakers is to devise and implement policies that will
allow Indonesia to recover from the economic crisis and stimulate broad-based growth to mitigate
the hardships of those most adversely affected. Together with banking, the industry sector, which
has strongly contributed to the growth of the Indonesian economy in the past decades, has been
the hardest hit by the economic crisis. The depth of the crisis and the severity of the contraction of
industrial  output  have  been  exacerbated  by  the  legacy  of  distortionary  industrial  policies  that
restricted competition, favored large firms, promoted rent seeking, increased costs, impeded the
growth of SMEs, and led to a highly concentrated industrial structure. These distortions limit the
ability  of  private  investors  to  respond  to  new  opportunities,  inhibit  economic  restructuring,  and
increase the vulnerability of the industry sector to the adverse effects of a weak banking system
and external financial shocks.

 19

More  than  two  years  since  the  crisis  started,  there  is  a  pressing  need  for  decisive
76.
measures to build on the recent macroeconomic gains and rapidly restore confidence of investors,
lenders, and producers. Restoring confidence and growth requires a fundamental transformation
of the economy by removing the impediments to the development of a more competitive industry
sector. These include: (i) high transaction costs resulting from excessive licensing and regulatory
requirements;  (ii) concentrated  industrial  structure  dominated  by  a  few  large  firms;  (iii) an
inconsistent  and  inadequate  policy  framework  for  industrial  competition;  (iv)  inefficiencies  in
markets and resource allocation caused by protection of existing firms from foreign and domestic
competition;  (v) a discretionary  investment  policy  that  generates  uncertainty  and  discriminates
between  domestic  and  foreign  investment,  and  (vi) inefficiencies  and  delays  in  customs
procedures.

77. While  these  policies  have  impeded  the  economic  recovery,  their  adverse  effects  have
been  more  pronounced  on  SMEs,  which  can  ill  afford  the  high  transactions  costs  resulting  from
the complex regulatory framework. Historically, Indonesia promoted SME development through a
large  number  of  special  programs,  incentives,  and  concessions  to  encourage  their  growth,
reflecting a view that the sector was weak and in need of protection. This approach to the support
of  SMEs  is  no  longer  sustainable  given  the  ongoing  structural  adjustment  of  the  Indonesian
economy based on comparative and competitive advantage. With sharply constrained budgetary
resources,  the  Government  is  no  longer  in  a  position  to  channel  resources  directly  to  and  for
SMEs as in the past. The new economic environment requires a reorientation of policies to make
SMEs  efficient  and  competitive.  Special  concessions  and  incentives  protecting  SMEs  from
competitive  forces  will  render  them  inefficient  and  incapable  of  coping  with  the  new  market
conditions. International experience suggests significant benefits from SME support policies that
focus  less  upon  the  notion  of  size  per  se,  and  more  on  creating  a  business  climate  that
encourages the emergence of new and efficient firms.

78.
Addressing these issues will require a coordinated policy response to promote competition
and  facilitate  structural  change  through  smoother  entry  and  exit  by  firms,  both  foreign  and
domestic,  large  or  small.  Without  further  deregulation  that  reduces  the  high  cost  of  doing
business,  measures  to  strengthen  domestic  competition  will  not  be  successful.  Only  such
deregulation  will  ensure  that  markets  are  operated  efficiently  and  transparently,  so  that  when
resources are committed to commercial activities, there are reasonable prospects that they will be
employed  productively.  It  is  also  necessary  to  improve  governance,  strengthen  the  commercial
legal  environment  for  competition,  increase  transparency  and  consistency  in  the  policy  making
process, improve customs performance, and reduce corruption in the bureaucracy.

79.
Given  their  high  potential  for  growth,  the  Government’s  reform  strategy  includes  a
renewed policy focus on SME development. Many SMEs will grow significantly without exiting that
size category, while others will eventually become larger firms. This is in sharp contrast to micro
or household enterprises, which rarely graduate from their size class. A coordinated approach to
promoting  competition  and  leveling  the  playing  field  for  all  enterprises  will  promote  SMEs  with
corresponding  benefits  in  terms  of  broad-based  growth  of  employment  and  incomes.  With  the
revival  of  industrial  growth  and  the  industrialization  process,  the  distribution  of  manufacturing
employment is expected to shift out of household activities into wage employment. SMEs will play
an important role in absorbing this labor shift.

80.
Greater  competition  that  promotes  growth,  a  dynamic  SME  sector,  and  the  resulting
impetus to structural change will lead to a transformation of the highly concentrated structure of
industry  in  Indonesia  with  concomitant  benefits  in  terms  of  greater  efficiency  in  resource
allocation, reduced market power, and increased consumer welfare.

Strengthening Competition

a.

Strengthening the Commercial Legal and Regulatory Environment

82.
Beginning in 1998, as a part of the Program, the Government has initiated a far reaching
reform  of  the  commercial  legal  system  to  promote  competition  and  provide  individuals  and
businesses with greater certainty on their rights, and with predictability relative to their commercial
transactions  and  legal  relationships.  To  facilitate  resource  mobility  and  exit  mechanisms  the
Government  approved  a  new  Bankruptcy  Law  in  August  1998  and  issued  a  supplementary
Presidential  Decree  and  implementing  regulations  that  established  commercial  courts  with
exclusive 
jurisdiction  over  bankruptcy  proceedings,  permitted  qualified  private  sector
professionals  to  serve  as  receivers  and  administrators  in  bankruptcy  and  reorganization
proceedings,  and  specified  time  limits  for  the  proceedings.  Supported  by  a  number  of  aid
agencies,  the  Government  completed  training  for  the  first  group  of  commercial  court  judges,
receivers,  and  administrators.  Complementing  these  measures,  the  Jakarta  Initiative  has
established  a  mechanism  for  out  of  court  settlements  of  debt-restructuring  that  will  facilitate
corporate restructuring and resource mobility.

83.
However, both the court and out-of court avenues for debt resolution have suffered from
implementation difficulties and delays. The number of bankruptcy cases has been small, and the
quality  of  some  judgements  questionable.  The  out-of-court  avenue  for  restructuring  has  been
slow. The Government has, therefore, initiated a review with a view to developing a more effective
strategy. Based on this review, a Financial Sector Policy Committee was established in December
1999  to  implement  an  enhanced  restructuring  strategy,  and  IBRA  and  the  Government  were
empowered  to  take  steps  against  recalcitrant  debtors  including  that  of  referral  to  the  Jakarta
Initiative,  and  to  the  Attorney  General  for  initiation  of  bankruptcy  proceedings.  These  measures
significantly  strengthen  mechanisms  and  incentives  for  bankruptcy  proceedings  and  out-of-court
settlements  of  debt  restructuring,  and  are  complemented  by  a  renewed  focus  on  strengthening
insolvency  procedures  through  judicial  training  and  reform.  As  a  result  of  these  measures,  by
December 1999, 620 of 800 large debtors (i.e. with loans over Rp50 billion; these accounting for
70 percent  of  non-performing  loans)  had  signed  letters  of  commitment  with  specified  tests  of

cooperation; a data base has been created of 3,900 debtors with debts over Rp1 billion; and the
first round of legal actions initiated against 119 non-cooperating debtors.

3.

Rationalization of  Assistance to SMEs

97.
The  dynamics  of  SME  growth  have  important  implications  for  policy  making.  SMEs
operate  in  a  highly  competitive  and  risky  environment,  are  conservatively  leveraged,  and  use
small  amounts  of  capital  that  is  turned  over  rapidly.  Those  able  to  produce  for  a  niche  market,
adapting quality and cost to market demand, have high potential. The sector experiences high exit
and  entry  rates.  Rather  than  being  a  symptom  of  structural  weakness  that  requires  corrective
policies,  the  high  rate  of  entry  and  exit  reflects  the  flexibility  with  which  the  sector  adjusts  to
changing market conditions, including sharp macroeconomic downturns like that experienced by
Indonesia. The ongoing structural transformation of the economy provides opportunities for both
existing  and  new  SMEs,  and  requires  a  reorientation  of  the  approach  to  promoting  SMEs  away
from its previous focus on protecting the sector to one in which the focus is on providing it greater
flexibility.  The  thrust  of  the  policy  focus  should  thus  be  on  reducing  excessive  bureaucratic
interference  rather  than  on  seeking  additional  support  programs.  Where  support  programs  are
required  they  should  be  demand  driven  and  supplied  by  the  market  rather  than  Government
departments.

98.
Reflecting the above considerations, the Government’s primary objective is to identify and
set an appropriate overall strategy. The strategy will, in turn, set the direction for policy development
and  determine  what,  if  any,  specific  programs  are  required  for  SMEs.  Under  the  Program,  the
Government will enhance the efficiency of SMEs through industrial deregulation (which will reduce
transactions  costs),  more  effective  financial  intermediation,  and  improved  provision  of  business
and technical services. These policy reforms will be formulated and implemented in consultation
with stakeholders. The Government will launch surveys and studies to update information on the
impact  of  the  economic  crisis  on  SMEs  and  design  appropriate  policy  and  monitoring
mechanisms.

Economic and Poverty Impact

1.

Economic Impact

106.
In the long run, the Program will result in higher industrial productivity and efficiency.  The
Program’s  support  of  reforms  to  deregulate  entry  and  exit  will  raise  capacity  utilization  and
productivity  in  the  medium  term.  By  enhancing  competitive  pressures  these  policy  changes  are
expected  to  induce  technical  change,  innovation,  and  sustained  effort  to  raise  productivity  and
reduce costs. By encouraging FDI the Program eases barriers to the free flow of resources and
enhances access to technology and managerial and organizational expertise.

107. While  promoting  investment,  however,  the  Program  will  be  affected  by  the  broader
economic environment that affects investment decisions. The supply or investment response will
depend  critically  on  the  impact  of  stabilization  measures,  with  substantial  international  evidence
indicating that resumption of private investment may be delayed in the aftermath of stabilization.28
The initial contractionary monetary policy put pressure on interest rates, reducing investment and
growth of output. Despite recent declines in interest rates, there is continued investor reluctance
to  commit  resources  given  their  perceived  uncertainty  regarding  the  policy  regime.  The  sharp
decline in investment following the implementation of stabilization measures in 1998 is consistent
with international experience.  However, the Government's recent success in lowering inflation is
highly encouraging as experience from other countries shows that a sustained low inflation rate is
strongly associated with investment recovery.

PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS

A.

Benefits

127.
The  policy  and  institutional  reforms  supported  by  the  Program  will  promote  competition
and  efficiency,  reduce  the  costs  of  doing  business  in  Indonesia,  and  contribute  positively  to  the
restoration  of  economic  growth  and  development.  More  efficient  allocation  of  resources  is
expected to spur higher productivity and export growth across a wide range of industry sectors.

128. A  significant  outcome  is  a  transparent  and  predictable  policy  framework  for  trade  and
industrial policy making and implementation. This will particularly benefit SMEs, which will face a
more predictable and less costly business environment. The more conducive policy environment
under  the  Program  will  promote  broad-based  growth  in  the  real  sector  and  will  improve  wage
levels and employment. An expanding SME sector will stimulate demand for labor from household
and cottage industries where the poor are predominantly found in the urban manufacturing sector.
Together,  these  will  promote  structural  transformation  of  the  industrial  sector  and  shifting  of
workers  from  agriculture  and  nonwage  employment  to  higher  productivity,  higher  wage  jobs  in
industry and services. This growth in overall employment and the intersectoral shifting of workers
will  reduce  poverty.  This  effect  will  be  reinforced  by  the  expected  expansion  in  exports.  As
Indonesia’s manufacturing exports are labor intensive, export expansion will increase employment
and  incomes  directly  among  households  whose  main  asset  is  their  labor,  i.e.,  relatively  poor
households.

129. Reduction of the remaining nontariff barriers and the provision of subsidies, and removal
of  protection  will  contribute  to  reducing  opportunities  for  rent  seeking  and  corruption.  A  further
major expected benefit is the considerable simplification of business registration requirements that
will significantly reduce the opportunities for illegal payments to facilitate business.

B. 

Risks

132.
The  Government’s  management  of  the  reform  process  seeks  to  achieve  consensus
among  stakeholders,  while  maintaining  the  objectives  and  timetables  of  its  structural  reform
program.  The  key  concerns  are  the  adverse  transitional  consequences  of  labor  retrenchment,
subsidy reductions, and higher user fees that could provoke resistance from affected groups, slow
the pace of reforms, and jeopardize their sustainability. This risk is mitigated by the Government’s
strong  commitment  to  the  reform  agenda  as  well  as  by  the  provision  of  financial  support  by  the
international  community.  ADB  funding  for  the  Program  will  enable  the  Government  to  support
transfer programs that will help maintain consumption levels of groups most hard pressed by the
economic  crisis.  The  risk  of  policy  reversals  is  further  mitigated  by  governance  reforms  that
strengthen  the  role  of  independent  agencies  such  as  BI,  and  the  Commission  for  Competition
Supervision. Finally, measures taken to reduce economic rent seeking are expected to strengthen
public confidence in the reform program.

133. A second risk is the possibility that measures to rationalize subsidized credit policies will
be misconceived as reductions in credit and support for vulnerable sectors. This risk is mitigated
by the Program and the associated TA, which support public consultation and the participation of
SMEs in formulating more effective policies to promote the sector and meet its needs for business
services, credit, and capacity building.

134. A third risk is that bank and corporate restructuring will proceed at a slow pace. This would
mean  that  fewer  firms  would  be  able  to  take  advantage  of  the  opportunities  to  reposition
themselves provided by the improving industrial policy environment. This risk is mitigated by the
Government’s recent adoption of a more proactive strategy for industrial restructuring and by the
substantial assistance being provided by the International Monetary Fund, ADB, World Bank, and
bilateral funding agencies for bank and corporate restructuring.

1.
The  policy  actions  taken  under  the  Industrial  Competitiveness  and  Small  and  Medium
Enterprise Development Program are directly and indirectly pro-poor. The importance of SMEs

requirements  for  SME  growth  and  development:  (i) strengthening  competition,  (ii)  investment
promotion and trade facilitation, and (iii) promotion of SMEs.

3.
Passage  of  a  competition/antimonopoly  law  is  required  to  create  a  healthy  competitive
market  by  ending  the  sanction  of  monopolies,  monopsonies,  market  control,  and  collaboration
among business players that can result in unfair competition. An uncompetitive market results in
higher prices and restricted business and employment opportunities, and provides opportunities
for  rent  seeking.  The  law  prevents  big  businesses  from  using  their  position  to  hinder  small
businesses. A fair business practice law limits vertical integration and market share, but must be
sufficiently  flexible  to  accommodate  natural  monopolies  such  as  water  supply  and  to  avoid
penalizing  efficient  businesses.  For  this  reason  an  independent  commission  is  required  to
determine whether a company is engaged in a monopoly or not. Proper implementation of the
law requires technical competence, integrity, and autonomy of members of the commission, and
detailed and unambiguous implementing regulations.

4.
As  a  well-functioning  market  allows  smooth  exit  as  well  as  entry  of  companies,
a bankruptcy law is essential to protect debtors from nuisance petitions, to protect creditors from
deterioration of assets when there is no hope for the successful operation of the company, and
to ensure an equitable formal distribution to creditors. Under a bankruptcy law, employees are
considered  as  creditors  and  their  interest  in  back  wages  and  severance  pay  is  protected.
A bankruptcy court is required to review the bankruptcy plan of the debtor or creditors to ensure
that  is  fair,  equitable,  and  feasible.  An  effective  and  just  insolvency  law  can  contribute  to
investor confidence and accelerate resolution of private sector debt. This will help to revitalize
the  economy.  Mechanisms  for  voluntary  restructuring,  debt  resolution,  and  debt-equity
conversions  by  holding  companies  promotes  exit  and  improves  resource  mobility  as  an
alternative to liquidation thus enabling otherwise viable business concerns to continue.

competitiveness of most export commodities. As the current foreign exchange regime provides
market-based  protection  to  domestic  industries  against  imports,  acceleration  of  tariff  reduction

costs for domestic industries stimulating growth and employment.

the  Agency  for  National  Logistics  (BULOG)  Import  Monopoly,  (ID3)
Reduce  the  list  of  importer-producer  (IP)  and  importer-trader  (IT)

10.
This policy is aimed at speeding up the process of reducing non-tariff barriers (NTBs) to
international trade such as import licensing and quantitative restrictions. With the development
of a private and competitive network of traders throughout the archipelago, BULOG is no longer
needed  to  secure  the  supply  of  basic  food  commodities  such  as  rice.  While  BULOG  will
continue to play a role in providing national food security, it no longer needs to do so by acting
as  sole  importer.  NTBs  were  heavily  used  during  the  late  1970s  and  early  1980s  as  part  of  a
development  strategy  that  sought  to  conserve  foreign  exchange  and  provide  stimulus  to
domestic  industries.  While  the  Indonesian  development  strategy  has  since  turned  outward
toward  a  trade-oriented  global  market,  NTBs  are  no  longer  an  appropriate  part  of  its
development  strategy  and,  instead,  enable  rent  collection  by  companies  holding  sole  or
restricted  licenses  and  undue  protection  to  particular  industries.  While  prior  to  the  crisis  there
might have been a concern that some industries may be adversely affected by competition from
imports,  this  concern  should  be  mitigated  by  the  natural  protection  offered  these  industries  by
the fall of the rupiah. NTBs on basic food stuffs such as sugar, garlic, and soybeans and other
items  such  as  plastics  result  in  higher  consumer  prices.  The  large  number  of  NTBs  on
intermediate manufacturing goods also increases production costs, affects the competitiveness
of downstream industry, and reduces opportunities for growth and employment. This effect will
be  removed  by  the  conversion  of  IP  and  IT  licenses  into  transparent  and  nondiscriminatory
instruments such as general licenses, or conversion into duties or excise taxes thus removing
rent-seeking opportunities. Licenses required for environmental or health considerations will be
made more transparent.

This  has  resulted  in  policies  that  have  rationed  foreign  investment  opportunities  by  sector,
location, and size of investment. In addition, the implementation of foreign investment screening
and  approvals  has  been  subject  to  complex  and  somewhat  uncertain  procedures  including

large  enterprises  that  have  been  in  place  since  the  late  1970s  have  failed  to  bring  about  a
deepening  of  linkages  between  large  and  small  industries.  While  some  large  industries  have
taken on a social mission to develop small industries, many others put off by the rigidities of the

Policy Area IIIB: Improve efficiency of financial intermediation

15.
Directed  subsidized  credit  lending  schemes  have  been  a  source  of  frustration  as
channeling  banks  bear  responsibility  for  loan  repayment,  borrowers  experience  hidden  costs
and delays in accessing the credit, and prospective borrowers perceive that access to credit has
been captured by better connected borrowers. Directed credit schemes have been plagued by
poor  repayment  performance  linked  to  rent-seeking  opportunities  by  banking  and  Government
officials and other credit delivery problems. As a result some borrowers were unable or did not
feel obligated to repay. Responsibility for loan repayment and lack of familiarity of the bank with
the intended beneficiary group has contributed to the capture of directed credit by non-intended
beneficiaries  known  to  the  bank.  While  directed  credit  may  continue  to  serve  as  an  important
policy  tool  for  the  Government,  its  channeling  terms  and  availability  must  be  clear,  and
usefulness  demonstrated.  The  number  of  schemes  should  be  streamlined  and  terms  and
conditions  standardized  and  known.  It  is  important  to  reduce  the  incentives  for  rent-seeking
behavior  or  capture  by  other  consumer  groups.  For  this  reason  the  gap  between  the  rate  for
subsidized  lending  and  commercial  lending  should  be  narrowed  and  appropriate  risk-sharing
incentives  established  as  this  will  reduce  the  scope  for  informal  charges,  the  incentives  for
diversion of lending to other borrowers, and improve the effectiveness of targeting and delivery.
Narrowing  the  gap  requires  establishing  an  appropriate  benchmark  to  avoid  inflation  of
outstanding  debt  obligations.  In  addition,  a  transparent  mechanism  for  assessing  subsidies  is
required  to  allocate  resources  and  subsidies  across  sectors  and  to  ensure  appropriate
budgetary allocation.  Bringing SME  credit into the budget and the use of public audit will help
ensure that funds are used in an accountable fashion and that policymakers are able to assess
trade-offs and optimal levels of funding.
